SPROCLIB - Semantic Process Control Library
  • Analysis Package
  • Edit on GitHub

Analysis Package

The analysis package provides comprehensive tools for process control system analysis, including transfer functions, system analysis, and model identification.

Note

This is part of the modern modular structure of SPROCLIB. For legacy compatibility, see Legacy Package.

Submodules

Transfer Function

Transfer Function Analysis for SPROCLIB

This module provides transfer function representation and frequency domain analysis for linear time-invariant systems in process control applications.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

class analysis.transfer_function.TransferFunction(num: ~typing.List[float] | <MagicMock id='1744477270912'>, den: ~typing.List[float] | <MagicMock id='1744477269568'>, name: str = 'G(s)')[source]

Bases: object

Transfer function representation and analysis.

__init__(num: ~typing.List[float] | <MagicMock id='1744477270912'>, den: ~typing.List[float] | <MagicMock id='1744477269568'>, name: str = 'G(s)')[source]

Initialize transfer function G(s) = num(s)/den(s).

Parameters:

  • num – Numerator coefficients (highest order first)

  • den – Denominator coefficients (highest order first)

  • name – Transfer function name

classmethod first_order_plus_dead_time(K: float, tau: float, theta: float, name: str = 'FOPDT') → TransferFunction[source]

Create first-order plus dead time transfer function. G(s) = K * exp(-theta*s) / (tau*s + 1)

Parameters:

  • K – Process gain

  • tau – Time constant

  • theta – Dead time

  • name – Transfer function name

Returns:

TransferFunction object (without dead time for analysis)

classmethod second_order(K: float, zeta: float, wn: float, name: str = 'Second Order') → TransferFunction[source]

Create second-order transfer function. G(s) = K * wn² / (s² + 2*zeta*wn*s + wn²)

Parameters:

  • K – Process gain

  • zeta – Damping ratio

  • wn – Natural frequency

  • name – Transfer function name

Returns:

TransferFunction object

step_response(t: <MagicMock id='1744477268224'> | None = None, t_final: float = 10.0, input_magnitude: float = 1.0) → Dict[str, <MagicMock id='1744477267216'>][source]

Calculate step response.

Parameters:

  • t – Time vector (optional)

  • t_final – Final time if t not provided

  • input_magnitude – Step magnitude

Returns:

Dictionary with ‘t’ and ‘y’ arrays

bode_plot(w: <MagicMock id='1744477266208'> | None = None, plot: bool = True) → Dict[str, <MagicMock id='1744477271248'>][source]

Generate Bode plot data.

Parameters:

  • w – Frequency vector (optional)

  • plot – Whether to create plot

Returns:

Dictionary with frequency, magnitude, and phase data

poles_zeros() → Dict[str, <MagicMock id='1744477272256'>][source]

Get poles and zeros of transfer function.

stability_analysis() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Analyze system stability.

Calculate frequency response.

Parameters:

w – Frequency vector [rad/s]

Returns:

Tuple of (magnitude, phase, frequency)

Calculate impulse response.

Parameters:

  • t_final – Final time if t not provided

System Analysis

System Analysis for SPROCLIB

This module provides comprehensive system analysis tools including stability analysis, controllability/observability tests, and performance metrics.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

class analysis.system_analysis.SystemAnalysis(name: str = 'System Analysis')[source]

Comprehensive system analysis tools.

name – Analysis name

Analyze stability of linear system dx/dt = A*x.

Parameters:

  • A – State matrix

  • system_name – System name for reporting

Returns:

Dictionary with stability analysis results

Analyze controllability of system (A, B).

  • A – State matrix [n x n]

  • B – Input matrix [n x m]

Analyze disturbance rejection performance.

  • w – Frequency vector for analysis

Dictionary with disturbance rejection analysis

linearization_analysis(model_func: callable, x_ss: <MagicMock id='1744477843680'>, u_ss: <MagicMock id='1744477844016'>, epsilon: float = 1e-06) → Dict[str, <MagicMock id='1744477844352'>][source]

Linearize a nonlinear model and analyze the linear approximation.

Parameters:

  • model_func – Function f(x, u) returning dx/dt

  • x_ss – Steady-state states

  • u_ss – Steady-state inputs

  • epsilon – Perturbation size for finite differences

Returns:

Dictionary with linearization results

Model Identification

Model Identification for SPROCLIB

This module provides tools for system identification and model fitting from experimental data or step response tests.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

class analysis.model_identification.ModelIdentification(name: str = 'Model Identification')[source]

Bases: object

System identification and model fitting tools.

Initialize model identification.

Parameters:

name – Identification name

fit_fopdt(t_data: <MagicMock id='1744479147344'>, y_data: <MagicMock id='1744479147680'>, step_magnitude: float = 1.0, initial_guess: ~typing.Tuple[float, float, float] | None = None) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Fit First Order Plus Dead Time model to step response data.

Parameters:

  • t_data – Time data

  • y_data – Response data

  • step_magnitude – Magnitude of step input

  • initial_guess – Initial parameter guess (K, tau, theta)

Returns:

Dictionary with fitted parameters and metrics

fit_sopdt(t_data: <MagicMock id='1744479148016'>, y_data: <MagicMock id='1744479148352'>, step_magnitude: float = 1.0, initial_guess: ~typing.Tuple[float, float, float, float] | None = None) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Fit Second Order Plus Dead Time model to step response data.

Parameters:

  • t_data – Time data

  • y_data – Response data

  • step_magnitude – Magnitude of step input

  • initial_guess – Initial parameter guess (K, tau1, tau2, theta)

Returns:

Dictionary with fitted parameters and metrics

fit_transfer_function(freq_data: <MagicMock id='1744479148688'>, magnitude_data: <MagicMock id='1744479149024'>, phase_data: <MagicMock id='1744479149360'>, model_order: ~typing.Tuple[int, int] = (2, 2)) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Fit transfer function to frequency response data.

Parameters:

  • freq_data – Frequency data [rad/s]

  • magnitude_data – Magnitude data (linear scale)

  • phase_data – Phase data [radians]

  • model_order – Transfer function order (numerator, denominator)

Returns:

Dictionary with fitted transfer function

Validate fitted model against independent validation data.

Parameters:

  • validation_data – Dictionary with ‘t’ and ‘y’ arrays

  • model_type – Type of model (‘fopdt’, ‘sopdt’)

Returns:

Dictionary with validation metrics

analysis.model_identification.fit_fopdt(t_data: <MagicMock id='1744479150704'>, y_data: <MagicMock id='1744479151040'>, step_magnitude: float = 1.0, initial_guess: ~typing.Tuple[float, float, float] | None = None) → Dict[str, float][source]

Fit First Order Plus Dead Time model to step response data.

Parameters:

  • t_data – Time data

  • y_data – Response data

  • step_magnitude – Magnitude of step input

  • initial_guess – Initial parameter guess (K, tau, theta)

Returns:

Dictionary with fitted parameters and metrics

Quick Usage

Transfer Function Analysis:

from analysis.transfer_function import TransferFunction
from analysis.system_analysis import step_response, bode_plot

# Create a transfer function
tf = TransferFunction([1], [1, 1], name="First Order")

# Analyze step response
response = step_response(tf)

# Generate Bode plot
bode_data = bode_plot(tf, plot=True)

Model Identification:

from analysis.model_identification import fit_fopdt
import numpy as np

# Generate sample data
t = np.linspace(0, 20, 100)
y = 2 * (1 - np.exp(-t/3))  # FOPDT response

# Fit FOPDT model
result = fit_fopdt(t, y)
print(f"K={result['K']:.2f}, tau={result['tau']:.2f}")
